mechpy¶

Classes¶

Define stress/strain tensors.

class mechpy.Stress(stresses)¶

Bases: mechpy._tensor.Tensor

Stress tensor.

principal¶

Array of principal stresses.

The array format is:

\[\begin{split}\left[ \begin{matrix} (\sigma_{xy})_1 & (\sigma_{xy})_2 & (\tau_{xy})_\text{max} \\ (\sigma_{yz})_1 & (\sigma_{yz})_2 & (\tau_{yz})_\text{max} \\ (\sigma_{zx})_1 & (\sigma_{zx})_2 & (\tau_{zx})_\text{max} \end{matrix} \right]\end{split}\]
vonMises()¶

The equivalent von Mises stress of the stress tensor.

class mechpy.Strain(strains)¶

Bases: mechpy._tensor.Tensor

Strain tensor.

stype¶

Strain type.

Must be ‘engineering’ or ‘tensor’ strain.

Notes

Only affects shear strains (i.e. \(\varepsilon_4\), \(\varepsilon_5\), and \(\varepsilon_6\)). Using Voigt notation, the relationship is defined:

\[\begin{split}\underbrace{ \left[ \begin{matrix} \varepsilon_1 \\ \varepsilon_2 \\ \varepsilon_3 \\ \varepsilon_4 \\ \varepsilon_5 \\ \varepsilon_6 \end{matrix} \right] }_\text{contracted notation} = \underbrace{ \left[ \begin{matrix} \varepsilon_{11} \\ \varepsilon_{22} \\ \varepsilon_{33} \\ \gamma_{23} \\ \gamma_{31} \\ \gamma_{12} \end{matrix} \right] }_\text{engineering strain} = \underbrace{ \left[ \begin{matrix} \varepsilon_{11} \\ \varepsilon_{22} \\ \varepsilon_{33} \\ 2 \varepsilon_{23} \\ 2 \varepsilon_{31} \\ 2 \varepsilon_{12} \end{matrix} \right] }_\text{engineering strain}\end{split}\]

Functions¶

Miscellaneous functions used in mechpy.

mechpy.ms(applied, allowed, knockdown=1)¶

Calculate the margin of safety.

The margin of safety is calculated according to the following formula:

\[MS = \frac{F_{\text{app}}}{k F_{alw}} - 1\]

where

\(MS\) margin of safety
\(F_{\text{app}}\) applied load
\(F_{\text{alw}}\) allowable

Note

The applied and allowed values must have the same units.

Parameters:
  • applied (float) – applied stress, load, or strain
  • allowed (float) – the allowable strength
  • knockdown (float) – allowable knockdown factor (default=1)
Returns:

the margin of safety
Return type:

float

Notes

It is also possible to calculate a margin of safety using a failure index by substituting the failure index in for the applied value and setting the allowed value to 1
